Award.AwardTitle: UBM-Institutional: Integrated Undergraduate Research Experiences in Biological and Mathematical Sciences
Award.AbstractNarration:
This grant is an extension of the Principal Investigator's expiring UBM grant of the same title which is a collaboration among the Departments of Biology, Mathematics and Statistics at Texas A&M University (TAMU) to develop a multidisciplinary, undergraduate program in mathematical biology in which students participate in research projects at the interface of the mathematical and biological sciences. The proposed expansion has as its primary goals adding mathematical ecology to the scientific scope of the project and increasing the representation of African American students to the UBM cohort. To achieve these goals, the Department of Wildlife and Fisheries Sciences (WFSC) is added to the existing TAMU UBM collaboration, and Prairie View A&M University (PVAMU), a Historical Black College and University (HBCU) with a 90% African American enrollment within the Texas A&M University System, is added as a UBM partner institution.

An overarching goal of the proposed UBM program is the creation of a permanent undergraduate academic culture at the interface of the biological and mathematical sciences that promotes and facilitates undergraduate student participation in cutting edge scientific research, and that fosters the desire and academic preparedness of undergraduate students for graduate study and eventual scientific careers in the participating disciplines. Cutting edge research in the life sciences is increasingly dependent upon cutting edge mathematical and statistical methodologies. The proposed UBM program is intended to prepare next generation scientists, mathematicians and statisticians to meet these challenges, and an essential element in meeting this goal is developing a diverse scientific talent pool inclusive of historically underrepresented groups in the biological and mathematical sciences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Texas A&M University’s (TAMU) NSF-UBM project had three primary objectives:  engage undergraduate students in the biological and mathematical sciences in research at the interface between the biological and mathematical sciences; develop permanent undergraduate curricular infrastructure in quantitative and mathematical biology; broaden participation of undergraduate students from traditionally underrepresented groups in research and study in quantitative and mathematical biology. Significant accomplishments were achieved toward meeting all three objectives.

 

First and foremost, the UBM experience for undergraduate student participants was focused upon research. All student participants were active and vital members of an interdisciplinary research team throughout their involvement in the program. Each research team was co-directed by two participating faculty members, one from the biological sciences and one from the mathematical sciences, and pursued a program of research with significant biological and mathematical components. Students from biology gained an understanding of the vital role modern mathematics plays in addressing contemporary challenges in the life sciences, and students from mathematics saw the wealth of new mathematical questions that arise from across a broad spectrum of current challenges in the life sciences. The research areas considered by the students spanned a wide swath of biological and mathematical topic areas including:  quantitative ecology (developing mathematical models to assess and manage key fisheries and fish stocks, e.g. the key Red Drum fishery in the Gulf of Mexico); quantitative epidemiology (developing mathematical models for the spread of vector-borne zoonotic diseases, e.g. Lyme Disease in Texas and northern Mexico); quantitative neuroscience (developing mathematical models of experimentally observed coordinated ATP modulated circadian rhythms exhibited by ensembles of astrocytes); population biology (the Leslie matrix approach to modeling the structured growth of a streptococcus pneumonia  bacterial colony); ecological epidemiology (mathematical models for multispecies infectious disease transmission, e.g. Newcastle disease in wild parrots and domestic fowl in Peru).

 

Concerning the development of permanent undergraduate curricular infrastructure, TAMU’s UBM program led to the development of two new undergraduate degree options in the quantitative life sciences:  the Quantitative Biology Option to the B.S. degree in Biology and the Mathematical Biology Option to the B.S. degree in the Applied Mathematical Sciences. In support of these degree programs, four new courses were developed:  MATH 147/148 (Calculus for the Life Sciences), BIOL/MATH 285 (QBS, Quantitative Biological Seminar) and MATH 469 (Introduction to Mathematical Biology). These four courses are at the heart of a major paradigm shift at TAMU in how undergraduate students in the biological sciences are trained, in particular in the level of mathematical sophistication demanded of students from various life science departments in recognition of the increasing importance of mathematics in addressing current and future biological challenges. The one-credit-hour QBS class is taken every semester by students in the two new biology and mathematics quantitative biology degree options. The QBS is a research seminar in which students learn how to read the archival research journal literature to gain an understanding of the breadth of the subjects addressed in contemporary quantitative biology as well as the societal impact of the research.
